com.google.enterprise.connector.spi
Interface Document

All Known Implementing Classes:
SimpleDocument
public interface Document

Interface that represents a document. A document is a set of Properties that can be explored both as a map and a list. List-like functionality is provided through the nextProperty() and getProperty() methods. Map-like functionality is provided through the findProperty(String) method, discussed below. In addition, a Document has a special method checkpoint(), which produces a String that encapsulates the current document so that if this String is provided to TraversalManager.resumeTraversal(String), the traversal will resume from the next document after this one.

Similar to DocumentList and Property, the list functionality is based on a "cursor" concept, like that of java.sql.ResultSet. Initially, the cursor is positioned before the first Property. A call to nextProperty() both returns a boolean, indicating whether there are any more properties, and advances the cursor to point at the next one. A call to getProperty() returns the Property currently pointed to by the cursor.

The consumer of this structure:

  • Should never call getProperty() before first calling nextProperty(). The implementor of this interface may throw an IllegalStateException if that happens.
  • Should never refer to a Property object obtained by getProperty() after a subsequent call to nextProperty() unless that subsequent call returns false. In other words, a Property object becomes invalid as soon as another valid Property is obtained.

Unlike DocumentList and Property, which only provide list-like access, this interface also provides map-like access. Map-like access is provided through findProperty(String), with getProperty().

A call to findProperty(String) returns true or false, depending on whether this document has a property of the specified name. If it returns true, then the next call to getProperty() will return that property.

The caller must not mix list access with map access. After the first call to nextProperty(), the caller may no longer call findProperty(String). In addition, the first call to nextProperty() will always return the first property--in particular it will not return the "next" property following the previous one accessed by the last findProperty(String), with findProperty(String) call.

The typical pattern for consuming an object that implements this interface is this (disregarding exception handling): 

 Document doc = ...
 Property specialProp;
 if (doc.findProperty(specialPropName1)) {
   specialProp = doc.getProperty();
   doSomethingSpecial(specialProp);
 }
 if (doc.findProperty(specialPropName2)) {
   specialProp = doc.getProperty();
   doSomethingElseSpecial(specialProp);
 }
 ... etc. for other special properties ...
 Property prop = null;
 while (doc.nextProperty()) {
   prop = doc.getProperty();
   handleProp(prop);
 }

Method Detail

nextProperty

public boolean nextProperty()
                     throws RepositoryException
Moves the property cursor down one row from its current position. The property cursor is initially positioned before the first property; the first call to the method nextProperty makes the first property the current property; the second call makes the second property the current property, and so on.

Calls to findProperty(String) are not permitted after the first call to nextProperty(). The implementor may throw an IllegalStateException if the caller violates this rule.

Returns:
true if the new current property is valid; false if there are no more properties
Throws:
RepositoryException - if a repository access error occurs

findProperty

public boolean findProperty(java.lang.String name)
                     throws RepositoryException
Finds a property by name. If the current document has a property with that name, then it becomes the current property: that is, the next call to getProperty will return the named property. All calls to this method must be done before the first call to nextProperty; the implementor may throw an IllegalStateException if the caller violates this rule.

Parameters:
name - The name of the property to find
Returns:
true if the new current document has a valid property with the requested name; false if not
Throws:
RepositoryException - if a repository access error occurs

getProperty

public Property getProperty()
                     throws RepositoryException
Returns the current Property

Returns:
the current Property
Throws:
RepositoryException

checkpoint

public java.lang.String checkpoint()
                            throws RepositoryException
Provides a checkpoint that can be used to control traversal. The implementor should provide a string that can be used by the framework to resume traversal starting just after this document. The framework will typically call this method on the last document it has chosen to process (for whatever reason: scheduling, completion of all documents currently available, etc.) It will persist this string, so that it can be recovered after a crash if necessary. When it chooses to restart traversal, it will supply this string in a call to TraversalManager.resumeTraversal(String).

Returns:
A string that can be used by a subsequent call to the TraversalManager.resumeTraversal(String) method.
Throws:
RepositoryException - if a repository access error occurs
